body: Hi Alessandro, Prism is similar to any other radiance material. Just add them to the library and use the name or connect the full material definition to the component. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/Fp4OwEQ0362gxAbGlB2nWDUEnEVudVPlYZzs08WxbIo*u2IgjH*yL9HgxKiHXQM*sZe0rw*Axo2juALGaNw1ET224ohpROwN/prism_modeling.png) [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/Fp4OwEQ0363ZHzCGuNBVNnnxwYQJeEmpesYzLN1hFlGacuxRvjizY2OEAg88j7P6k87HLwUqZEcXuvSDB35kYKk5ICW036ti/prism_glass_1_IMG_Perspective.PNG) I made an example file based on this document: [http://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.4214.pdf](http://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.4214.pdf) - Check page 12. There are references that are mentioned in the document that you can check to learn more about the input values. I played with radiance input parameters but couldn't get that far with my laptop. I really like to what a high-res render would look like and if it is possible to get different colors by setting up the input parameters for prism surface correctly.
